g.text: Along with the carbon emissions drop was
a dramatic improvement in other parameters such as clean air quality. Moreover, longer
behavioural impacts are also possible: a dramatic acceleration of digital technologies in
mmunications, travel, retail trade and transport. The question however is whether the world might
intensive path of recovery, or to a different future, and the choice of policies
in shaping this future. Studies generally sugges
t that the gains from long
on future global warming will be limited and depend more on the nature of public policy actions and
term commitments by countries to raise their ambitions, not just on climate but on sustainable
(Barbier 2020; Barbier and Burgess 2020; Forster et al. 2020; Gillingham et al.
The positive lesson is clear: opportunities exist for accelerating structural
orientation of economic activity modes to a low
carbon use strategy in areas such
as coal use in energy consumption and surface transport, city congestion an
cost alternatives exist and offer potentially dramatic gains
A new consensus and compact towards such a structural change and economic stimulus
may therefore need to be redrawn worldwide, where an accelerated low carbon transition is a priority;
and accelerated climate finance to spur these investments may gain by becoming fully and rapidly
growth and macroeconomic strategies for governments,
central banks, and private financial systems alike. If that were to happen, COVID
turning point for sustainable climate policy and financing. Absent that, a return to ‘business
modes will mean a likely down
cycle in climate financing and investments in the near
Expectations that the recovery package stimulus will increase economic activity rely on the assumption
that increased credit investment will have a positive effec
. The argument for a green recovery also draws on the experience from the
2009 (GFC) recovery, in which large economies such as China,
South Korea, the US and the EU
observed that green investments propelled the development of new
industrial sectors. Noticeably, this had a positive net effect on job creation when compared to the
a et al. 2018; Jaeger et al. 2020)
finance possible response see Section 15.6.3. Here, we conclude
with the options for reviving a better
some combinations of five possible elements:
(a) Reaffirmation of a strong financial agenda in future Conference of Parties’ meetings, and a new
collective finance target, which will need to be undertaken by 2025. Given that the shortfalls in
re likely to be acute for developing regions and especially the more debt
(Dibley et al. 2021; Elkhishin and Mohieldin 2021; Laskaridis 2021; Umar et al. 2021)
developed countries may wish to step up their collective support
possibility is to expedite the new SDR issuance allocation rules for the 650 billion USD recently (2021)
approved, most of which will go to increase the reserves of G
voluntarily reallocated towards the needs o
resources potentially ‘larger than the Marshall Plan in today’s money’
trap of current high cost of finance that effectively lowers green electricity production poss
Africa for a cost optimal pathway. Other initiatives could also include G
(especially with the lead taken by the developed members for cross
burdening public resources in developing countries
) running coordinated fiscal deficits to accelerate the
financing of low carbon investments (‘green fiscal stimulus’).
(b) introducing new actions, including regulatory, to take some of the risks off
in climate mitigation investment and insurance. This could
